_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Policy:
The City of San Diego Water Department has and continues to design facilities, operate and maintain equipment and commit the personnel and resources to meet or exceed industry standards and regulatory requirements.  The City developed and implemented the City's Process Safety Management/ Risk Management Prevention Program that provides a systematic approach to employee involvement, safety awareness and program assessment.

Plant Description:
The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant was built in the early 1950's and became an architecture center piece of the community due to its beauty and mission style design. The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant has a maximum water treatment capacity of 200-million gallons per day (mgd). The facility is located on a mesa on relatively flat terrain bounded by the Lake Murray Reservoir to the north, and by residential areas in other directions bordering the City of La Mesa.  There is elevated terrain across the reservoir, and downward-sloping terrain to the south.

Alvarado Water Treatment Plant uses a combined form of chlorine to disinfect water, making it suitable for use in the City of San Diego's drinking water distribution system and for sale to other agencies. The chlorine is received in one-ton pressurized liquid cylinders at the Chlorine Storage Room in the Raw Water Chemical Building.

Commitment:
The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant has a well trained and committed operations and maintenance staff with a record of over 50 years of using chlorine safely.  To support the efforts of continued safe handling and use of chlorine at the Alvarado Water Treatment Plant, senior management has committed to the development of a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program under the guidelines of State and Federal mandates which has involved complete engineering reviews of the chlorine feed system and design certification.  The Alvarado Water Treatment Plant periodically review the RMP program and look for ways to improve safe

ty.

Program Compliance:
The Risk Management Prevention and Process Safety Management Programs have been developed and implemented.  The Risk Management Prevention is in fulfillment of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR PART 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions and the California Code of Regulations Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 - California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The Process Safety Management Program is in fulfillment of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's (OSHA) 1910.119, as well as Cal/OSHA's California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials.
 
Offsite Consequence Analysis:
In accordance with 40 CFR PART 68, Subpart D, "worst-case" release scenarios and alternative scenarios are required to be completed to determine the distance to endpoint (e.g., under worst-case weather, the substance could travel X distance before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public).  

On April 9, 2004, EPA revised the RMP rule to remove the requirement that facilities include a brief description of off-site consequences of hypothetical worst-case and alternative releases as par of the Executive Summary. This information has been removed to address security concerns.

Safety Elements:
Safety elements include administrative controls, engineering controls and personal protective equipment (PPE).  

Administrative elements may include but are not limited to:
- Standard operations
- Maintenance procedures
- Training
- Record Keeping

Engineering controls may include but are not limited to:
- Facility alarms
- Isolation Valves
- Chlorine Scrubbers

PPE controls may include but are not limited to:
- Self Contained Breathing Apparatus 
- Chemical Protective Overalls
- Safety Goggles

Several administrative and engineering controls are installed on the chlorine process system to enhance the facility's emerg

sponding to a chlorine release or chlorine release threat.  The Plan contains a flow chart which visually presents this information for both controlled and uncontrolled release scenarios.  The basic emergency response steps include:
- Verification/Situation Assessment
- Isolation
- Notification
- Reporting
- Remediation & Recovery
- Incident Investigation
- Implementation of Improvements
- Training

Accident History:
The City has maintained a clean record of accidental releases of acutely hazardous materials. No significant accidental releases of chlorine have occurred within the last five years requiring plant evacuation or requiring off site evacuation or consequences.
 
Compliance Audit:
The most recent compliance audit was conducted in accordance with RMP/PSM requirements by an outside consultant in 2013.  The audit was to evaluate the adequacy of the PSM and RMP programs and provide recommendations of improvements.
